ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: all the details ever imaginable about congress
A comprehensive understanding of the US Congress.
I learned more about how Congress functions.

I learned about many different facets of the U.S. Congress, including the myth of coequal branches; the informational theory, distributional theory, and partisan theory; the influence of money in Congress; the structure of congressional staff, and more!
I learned a great deal about the US Congress and how the US political system works.
I developed basic knowledge about the US congress.
I learned about the intricacies of the United States Congress. There is a lot to learn about this one institution and Professor Fairdosi did a great job of laying the foundational knowledge about it.
I learned about US Congress
General overview of Congress' role in politics, society, and culture, both historically and in modern times
I developed a basic knowledge of theories behind congress and some key terms. This class did not feel particularly in depth.
I learned a lot about the United States Congress and feel confident that I could recite this knowledge in pertinent conversation and apply it to future classes about American Government.
I have learned so much about the ways in which congress works and interacts with the other two branches of government.
I learned a lot about the structures and procedure of US congress
Learned a ton about the US Congress. Learned the interworks of the government.
A general understanding of the functions of congressional procedure.
This class provided insights into the institutional structures which underly the Congress, as well as the changes within these structures over time.
Learned about rules, strategy, and the structure of congress
I gained insight on the United States Congress, how it works, its connections to the United States, and its many makeups. I learned a lot about U.S. Congress, writing, and history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: prof fairdosi

Strengths: Professor Fairdosi. 

Weaknesses: Lectures are somewhat boring.
I think the class was very digestible and easy to understand which was beneficial. I also think the discussion sections were fun and engaging.

This class was great BECAUSE of Prof. Fairdosi. The course structure, the topics he covered, the insights and unique perspective he brought to the classroom made this class incredible. I see that next semester this class is being taught by a different professor, and the class seems to be completely different. I don't think you could base these evaluations as reference for that class, so I'm glad I took this when I did.
Strengths: The course was very well organized and comprehensive. Slides were always posted to Canvas, and recordings were often available as well.
It is a very good basic overview, but for someone who already knows the basics of Congress you will learn very little.

Strengths: Very managable workload and Fairdosi is a great teacher
Weakness: Sometimes the pace/lectures could be a bit slow, but that is also just the nature of some of the most foundational topics
Great course no weaknesses

Strengths: engaging and relevant to current topics, covering some information that wouldn't be found in textbooks
Weaknesses: a little disorganized at times and with confusing grading

Strengths: Dr. Fairdosi is a great guy and did a great job of fostering a welcoming class environment.

Weaknesses: The lectures dragged and werent very well organized. Class also didnt lend very well to developing a solid critical understanding of concepts.

The strength of this course is the clarity of the lectures. The weakness of this course was the midterm and final exam organization: both were 5 page papers on one topic, so it really limited your ability to show critical thinking by engaging with one topic only. It could be improved by 2-3 smaller prompt responses.
Honestly no weaknesses. Great course and very engaging.

This course was incredibly dry. What couldve been a valuable semester of looking critically and congress and its structures was instead a series of slow lectures focused on the least interesting parts of congress in the abstract, not at all contextualized by real world examples. Prof Fairdosi is great but this syllabus was not. Engagement was extremely low.
More engaging lectures

A strength of this course was the way in which discussion sections allowed students to share their perspective on course topics in a respectful environment. A weakness is that there was inconsistency relating to the density of material within differing lectures.
Strengths: great professor, clear expectations. Weaknesses: could be boring or straightforward at times

Strengths: great introductory course on the U.S. Congress, works well as an extension to introductory political science; Weaknesses: section was really unnecessary and at times redundant, would recommend that this class switch to a seminar-style or have only optional section

One strength is the teaching style. Professor Fairdosi teaches in a concise and easy-to-understand way. He is able to make complex topics understandable. His teaching style, lecture structure, and organization were great strengths. A weakness could be that some lecture topics weren't interesting (but they were important and contributed to overall knowledge of U.S. Congress).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
yes
great credit for poli sci majors
Yes! It gives a good, foundational understanding to the US Congress.

I would recommend this course if it was taught by prof fairdosi. If not, I couldn't necessarily recommend it. The topics we covered gave such an excellent overview and the structure and insight prof. fairdosi offered was incredible. This was BY FAR my favorite class this semester, and I genuinely looked forward to coming to each and every class. The topics were always interesting and engaging, and the small-ish nature of the class gave a great opportunity to discussion.

I would certainly recommend this course to any other student who is interested in taking a deep dive into the US Congress and learning more about its philosophical underpinnings, its present-day status and role, etc.
If you don't know anything about Congress, I would definitely recommend it. If you do, maybe not.
Yes.

Yes! Fairdosi is a great professor. Any chance you get to take a class with him, you should. He is very knowledgeable and passionate about politics and Congress and fills the course with meaningful anecdotes. He always makes you feel welcome and like a part of a class and not just a number, which I have felt in other classes with different professors before.
The course was interesting for those interested in politics or a career on the Hill.
I would recommend this course to another student for sure!

Yes, if you're interested in learning about this institution that is central to American politics and society, although do be prepared to go through some very basic information at the beginning of the course

Yes. I think the course covered some important topics for people interested in understanding the workings and history of the US Congress/people interested in civics/politics in general. The course is also very low stress so I'd recommend taking it as a 5th class and just trying to get the most out of it by trying to engage as much as you can with the discussion section conversations.
Your entire grade is based on two essays that you get no feedback for. I also found the class fairly dull. However, if youre looking for an easy A- to an A, this is a great course to take.

I would recommend this course to any student, a political science major or someone trying to fulfill their social science credit. The class is slow paced and full of knowledge, while the instructor is very adaptative to learning needs and studies queries.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, especially if congress is something youre interested in. If not, I still believe its important to know the way in which the government works
Yes this course is fantastic and very interesting
Yes. Great professor and very interesting.
This is a great gut for political science majors. Very low time commitment and will not take away from your other classes while gaining a credit for the major.

I would recommend this course to any student who wishes to learn more about the institutional structures which underly Congress, or for those students who wish to learn more about how these structures interact with the institutional structures underlying other branches of the US gov.
Yes! Especially for political science majors

Absolutely. Fairdosi is a great professor who really levels with students in terms of workload and class demands. He understands the importance of work/life balance and does a great job conveying information without a ton of sidework.

Yes!! The lecture were well-structured and the workload was very manageable. All of the topics were well-taught and relevant to current U.S. Congress. Anyone interested in American government should take this course.
